For a collection of N particles, what determines whether they can be accurately described using classical Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics?

answer.content: The de Broglie wavelength of the particles.
Ratio of separation between particles to their de Broglie wavelength.

If the particles have de Broglie wavelengths of 100 nm, would you expect Classical or Quantum Mechanics be more suited to describing their interaction?
What is the thermal de Broglie wavelength of a particle?

answer.content: The average de Broglie wavelength of a gas phase particle at some temperature T.
The most probable de Broglie wavelength of a gas phase particle at some temperature T.
The maximum de Broglie wavelength of a gas phase particle at some temperature T.
The minimum de Broglie wavelength of a gas phase particle at some temperature T.

vignette.content: The main reason for assigning a thermal de Broglie wavelength to each particle in a system of N particles is because typically, in most systems with N particles in thermal equilibrium, each particle

answer.content: has a well-defined average energy of 3/2 k<sub>B</sub>T.
has a different quantized energy level.
has not have a well-defined average spin per particle.
does not obey the Pauli Exclusion Principle.

vignette.content: The thermal de Broglie wavelength λ of a particle of mass m is defined by which equation?
Classical statistics are accurate as long as the mean distance between particles

answer.content: equals the thermal de Broglie wavelength of the particles.
equals the thermal de Broglie wavelength of the particles.
is much less than the thermal de Broglie wavelength of the particles.

Generally speaking, the most practical way to vary the thermal de Broglie wavelength of the particles is to
Electrons in a metal are often called an electron-gas. At room temperature, the thermal de Broglie wavelength of an electron is

answer.content: much smaller than the typical electron-electron separation distance.
comparable to the typical electron-electron separation distance.
much larger than the typical electron-electron separation distance.

vignette.content: The four particles listed below all have the same thermal energy. Which would have the smallest thermal de Broglie wavelength?
An ideal gas is made of identical quantum particles (i.e. atoms), yet classical Maxwell Boltzmann statistics are perfectly valid. This is true because the separation between gas atoms

answer.content: is typically much larger than the thermal de Broglie wavelength of a gas atom.
is comparable to the thermal de Broglie wavelength of a gas atom.
is typically much smaller than the thermal de Broglie wavelength of a gas atom.

vignette.content: When discussing a collection of N particles, the words “distinguishable” and “indistinguishable” can cause confusion because they

answer.content: have definitions which are different from the everyday use of the words.

vignette.content: Suppose you have a deck of 52 identical cards (say all 4♣), each card is

answer.content: indistinguishable because they are all identical.
distinguishable even though they are all identical.

vignette.content: A deck of 52 identical cards (say all 4♣) are said to be distinguishable primarily because

answer.content: there are always small differences between them.
any one card can be marked and then identified later on.
they can always be arranged in some way.

vignette.content: Can identical classical particles like Ar atoms be distinguished?

answer.content: Yes, because in principle it is possible to follow the motion of one Ar atom over time.
No, it is impossible because all Ar atoms are identical.

vignette.content: Can identical quantum particles be distinguishable?

answer.content: Answer depends if their motion can be followed over time.
Yes, it is possible because we can always follow their motion over time.
No, it is impossible because we can never follow their motion over time.

vignette.content: What does it mean when we say identical particles are indistinguishable?

answer.content: The particles have at least one intrinsic property which is different.
The particles have no intrinsic property which is different.
The particles have no intrinsic properties whatsoever.
We cannot follow their motion over time.

vignette.content: In classical mechanics, we say N identical particles are distinguishable because, in principle,

answer.content: a particle cannot be “marked” at some point in time.
each particle has at least one intrinsic property which is different.
each particle can be “marked” at some point in time so their motion can be followed.
even though each particle can be “marked” at some point in time, their motion cannot be followed.

vignette.content: In quantum mechanics, N identical particles are indistinguishable if

answer.content: their motion cannot be followed over time, even if we try.
they have no intrinsic property which is different.
they cannot be marked in any way.
their motion can be followed over time.

vignette.content: Is it possible for a system of N particles to switch from classical Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics to Bose-Einstein statistics as the temperature is lowered?
In a system comprised of two H atoms, can the two electrons be considered identical?

answer.content: Yes, because they have identical intrinsic properties.
No, because they are in different atoms.

vignette.content: In a system comprised of two H atoms, can the two electrons be considered distinguishable?

answer.content: Yes, to a good approximation, since the H atoms are well separated.

vignette.content: The concepts of “distinguishability” and “indistinguishability” affect the number of possible outcomes of certain events. If two six-sided, distinguishable die (one red and one green) are rolled together, how many outcomes are possible?

The concepts of “distinguishability” and “indistinguishability” affect the number of possible outcomes of certain events. If two six-sided, indistinguishable die (both are white with black dots) are rolled together, how many outcomes are possible?
Suppose a system of N particles is held at constant energy. What happens to the number of microstates if we magically switch all distinguishable particles into indistinguishable ones?

answer.content: Each macrostate will tend to have fewer microstates.
Each macrostate will have the same total number of microstates.
Each macrostate will tend to have more microstates.

vignette.content: A major difference between Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac statistics is that

answer.content: Bose-Einstein statistics only apply to half integer spin particles.
Bose-Einstein statistics only apply to integer spin particles.
There really is no major difference.

vignette.content: A major consequence of the indistinguishability of quantum particles is that the presence of one particle in a particular quantum state

answer.content: strongly influences whether another identical particle will be in the exact same state.
has no influence whatsoever on whether another identical particle will be in the exact same state.
weakly influences whether another identical particle will be in the exact same state.

The three common phases of matter are
The crystalline phase of solid matter is characterized by

answer.content: a random spatial arrangement of atoms.
a highly ordered spatial arrangement of atoms.
crystals that only have the shape of cubes.

vignette.content: The primary difference between a primitive and conventional unit cell is that primitive unit cells

answer.content: always have more than one atom within the unit cell.
have only one atom within the unit cell.

vignette.content: X ray diffraction patterns are used to characterize

answer.content: the arrangement of planes of atoms within a crystal.
the atoms and/or molecules that comprise a crystal.
the electronic structure of a crystal.

vignette.content: Bragg scattering experiments are usually performed to

answer.content: identify the type of atoms in a crystalline solid.
identify the orientation of atoms in a crystalline solid.
identify the melting temperature of a crystalline solid.
identify the bonding of atoms in a crystalline solid.

vignette.content: What type of electromagnetic radiation is typically used in Bragg scattering experiments?
What is the approximate wavelength of electromagnetic radiation used in Bragg scattering experiments?
In Bragg scattering, the condition to produce constructive interference patterns, also called diffraction patterns, from a crystalline solid is nλ=d sinθ. What does d represent?

answer.content: The size of the crystalline solid under study.
The distance between two parallel planes of atoms.

vignette.content: When discussing crystalline solids, the term “unit cell” refers to

answer.content: the smallest unit from which an entire crystal can be built by translation.
a volume that contains only one atom.
one crystalline grain in a piece of material with multiple crystal grains.
the concentration of atoms in a solid.

vignette.content: What information is not needed when the structure of a crystalline solid is specified?

answer.content: The dimension of the unit cell.
The angles of the three vectors defining the outside edges of the unit cell.
The rigidity (or strength) of the unit cell.
The positions of each atom within the unit cell.

answer.content: is valid because the triangle matches the symmetry of the atomic arrangement.
is not valid because the triangle drawn is not a right triangle.
is not valid because triangles cannot be translated to fill all space.
is valid because the triangle can be rotated to match the symmetry of the atomic arrangement.

vignette.content: How many distinct crystal systems have been identified in nature?
A simple “working” definition of a crystal lattice might be

answer.content: a 3-dimensional grid system that fills all space.
a matrix specifying the rotation properties of a crystal system.
a network of patterns describing the symmetry of a crystalline material.
a tensor specifying the translation properties of a crystal system.

vignette.content: A crystal lattice is most useful in describing which type of matter?
Bravais is credited with defining ________ different space-filling lattice types in three dimensions.
Bravais lattice sites

answer.content: are always associated with the positions of atoms.
are not necessarily associated with the positions of atoms.
specify where impurities are located in a crystalline solid.
are mostly used to describe distortions in crystalline solids.

WWhich cubic Bravias lattice has only one atom in a unit cell?
Miller indices are primarily

answer.content: a notation to describe directions and identify families of planes in lattices and crystals.
a guide to indexing allowed wavevectors in crystalline solids.
a key to cataloging allowed energy eigenvalues in crystalline solids.
the locations of impurity atoms in crystalline solids.
